statement.text: Inflammatory abdominal aortic aneurysm (IAAA) is a distinct variant characterized by marked thickening of the aneurysm wall (≥5mm), perianeurysmal fibrosis, and adhesion to adjacent structures including duodenum, ureters, and vena cava. IAAA represents 3-10% of all AAAs.
statement.formal: IAAA: AAA + wall thickening ≥5mm + perianeurysmal fibrosis + adjacent structure involvement (duodenum, ureters, IVC)

explanation.intuition: While a typical aneurysm is like a thin-walled balloon, an inflammatory aneurysm is like a balloon wrapped in thick scar tissue that glues it to everything around it. This dense inflammatory reaction makes surgery more difficult because the normal tissue planes are obliterated - the aneurysm becomes 'stuck' to the intestine, the tube carrying urine from kidney to bladder, and major veins.
explanation.key_insight: The inflammatory process is thought to represent an autoimmune reaction to atherosclerotic debris in the aneurysm wall. Despite its name, IAAA is not primarily an infectious process. The fibrosis typically regresses after successful aneurysm repair.
explanation.technical_details: Histologically, IAAA shows marked adventitial and periadventitial fibrosis with lymphoplasmacytic infiltration. The inflammation extends into surrounding retroperitoneum. Associated IgG4-related disease should be considered, especially with other manifestations. CT characteristically shows a 'rim sign' - enhancing thickened aortic wall with surrounding soft tissue.
common_misconceptions: IAAA is an infected aneurysm - it is autoimmune/inflammatory, not infectious
All IAAA need open repair - EVAR may be appropriate if anatomy permits
Steroids are always required - medical therapy is adjunctive, not definitive
IAAA has higher rupture risk - rupture risk is similar to standard AAA by size

complications.duodenal_involvement: Adherence to third portion of duodenum
complications.ivc_involvement: May encase or compress inferior vena cava

definitions_glossary.inflammatory_AAA: AAA variant with wall thickening, fibrosis, and adhesion to adjacent structures
definitions_glossary.perianeurysmal_fibrosis: Dense fibrous tissue surrounding the aneurysm wall
definitions_glossary.IgG4_related_disease: Systemic fibroinflammatory condition that can manifest as IAAA
definitions_glossary.rim_sign: CT finding of enhancing thickened aortic wall in IAAA

mri_features: T2 hyperintense periaortic tissue in active inflammation

surgical_considerations.approach: Retroperitoneal approach may be preferred to avoid duodenal injury
surgical_considerations.evar_considerations: Feasible if anatomy permits; may reduce surgical morbidity

definition.@value: AAA variant with wall thickening, perianeurysmal fibrosis, and adhesion to adjacent structures

sources.citation: Hellmann DB, et al. Inflammatory abdominal aortic aneurysm. JAMA. 2007;297(4):395-400

learning_objectives: Recognize clinical and imaging features of IAAA
Understand surgical implications of perianeurysmal inflammation
Differentiate IAAA from mycotic and standard AAA
clinical_pearls: Always check for hydronephrosis on preoperative imaging
Consider IgG4-related disease workup if systemic features present
Fibrosis typically regresses after successful AAA repair
EVAR avoids the hostile retroperitoneum when anatomy permits
